CARNEGIE ENDOWMENT FOR INTERNATIONAL PEACE
UNITED NATIONS PLAZA AT 46TH STREET
NAEB HEn
NEW YORK 17, NEW YORK
CABLE ADDRESS INTERFAX
JUN 3 0 1958
AM
PM
27 May 1958
7l8|9|iptll|12|li2|3i4j6j6
I
Dear Mr. Underwood:
In response to your kind letter of June 5, I am sending you
under separate cover a half hour tape recording ’’Britain views the
United Nations, ” based on the Carnegie Endowment's publication,
Britain and the United Nations . The participants are as I listed them
except that Frederick Kuh, Washington correspondent for the Chicago
Sun-Times substituted for William Stringer. The time of the record¬
ing is 27’40” and it was recorded at a speed of 7 1/2 IPS.
If the recording is acceptable, I would appreciate any information
you may have about its distribution to your affiliates and, if it is not
too much trouble, the times that it might be heard, particularly in the
Washington , D.C and New York area. I realize the latter request is
difficult and I will understand if you cannot fulfill it.
Are there any objections on the part of NAEB to distributing this
tape to other outlets for^^either as a whole or part?
On behalf of the Carnegie Endowment, may I thank you for your
consideration of this program.
Sincerely yours,
Roger Lyons
Director of Public Relations
Mr. Robert E. Underwood, Jr.
Network Manager
National Association of Educational Broadcasters
University of Illinois
119 Gregory Hall
Urbana, Illinois
